FEWS forecasts dramatically worse for the next couple of months, and especially into early 2018.  However, to put it in context, the October - December season is generally one of low absolute famine risk.  That means that the poor Deyr rainfall in October will still see increased food production in the next couple of months, but much less than anticipated, and there is a dramatically increased vulnerability to famine when those food supplies run out in the next dry season (February onwards).

FEWS current situation update and October - January projection update released in last few hours.  In short, we are through the worst of the "starving period", but improvements across the next few months will be less than anticipated.  This increases the probability of a famine early in 2018.  (It also relatively increases the chance of a famine in the remainder of this year, but famines have a strong tendency to occur in the February to July season, rather than the period October-December, so the absolute risk will still be quite low in comparison.)

Time passes.  We are almost out of the danger period (generally identified as up until the end of September) and no news of famine yet.  My spreadsheet has the probability dropping below 4.5% in the last couple of days.  If the end-of-the-month report from FEWS has the forward predictions no worse than they presently are, then the probability will drop below 4.0%.

Three UN agencies have already warned there is a high risk of famine, meaning that the UN will likely be aware once it can be officially classified as a famine. While calling it a famine is politically charged, having been willing to declare a famine there in the recent past as well as in South Sudan shows a willingness to do so. Food donations seem to be all that is stopping the country from having another one, and the most recent rainy season failed them again. While the conditions for famine are quite high, preemptive action might at least delay the calling of a famine. However, competing priorities with Syria, South Sudan and Yemen among others make food donations less likely to be able to compensate for th food shortages.

Breaking it up into subquestions:
*  Are we missing something?  Could it be that some regions of Somalia are already in famine, but we are not aware?
*  Is the food security situation likely to improve or deteriorate later in the year compared to the present situation?
*  If it deteriorates, will it deteriorate enough to make a famine possible?
*  If a famine becomes possible, will humanitarian agencies be able to avert a famine?
*  If the criteria for a famine are met, will the UN declare a famine?

Reducing estimate by 3 points when considering the inability of Somalia as a failed state to distribute aid if the UN were to declare a famine. I believe that this makes the UN far more likely to move aid in Yemen or Nigeria where aid may be more efficient, making a declaration in Somalia even less likely.

Since inception of UN there have been ~20 major famines in the world, fewer have been declared by UN and never more than one in a single year. 2010 was first UN declared famine in the Horn in 30 years. Declaring a famine requires IPS phase 5 (meaning ~2,864 deaths per day); Somalia is roughly in phase 3 outside of particularly hot combat regions.

Based on http://www.fews.net/east-africa/somalia the situation seems quite dire. Much of the country is one step below famine and expected to stay there for the rest of the year. I think there's probably about a 40-60% chance of a famine.

The past and the present prove Somalia is a failed state and the distribution of food and health services is a difficult task.  The UN has limited resources like any entity and they are directing their resources to South Sudan currently.  Warlords rule Somalia and at this point in time, regardless of the actual circumstances, the UN will hold off on declaring famine in Somalia in 2017.  It was proven in the 90's that food and starvation are used as a tool of war in Somalia.

"A famine can be declared only when certain measures of mortality, malnutrition and hunger are met. They are: at least 20 per cent of households in an area face extreme food shortages with a limited ability to cope; acute malnutrition rates exceed 30 per cent; and the death rate exceeds two persons per day per 10,000 persons." >>> Source - http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=39113#.WZ_0UncjFAY

Looking at FEWS projections for the rest of year, they forecast emergency conditions in much of the country but nothing quite reaching the technical definition of a famine. That said, Somalia is a volatile place and I wouldn't be surprised if there was a more serious crisis.

- Somalia is facing worst drought in 40 years
- Civil war means parts of Somalia inaccessible to aid agencies.
- A fifth of the population lives in areas controlled by Al-shaabab, which is restricting aid access
Low rainfall this year, rainy season over in June, resurgent piracy means less government attention to farmers, and a desire to keep squeezing al-Shabab makes a late year declaration likely.

While the food shortage is expected to continue, given the UN's lack of desire to declare famine in Nigeria and other places, I'm skeptical they will do so for Somalia in the next four months. Additionally, these conditions have existed for several months without any significant move toward a declaration by the UN.
Somalia spends a lot of time on the cusp of famine.  Have to start somewhere, and this seems like a safe opening bid, but this obviously needs to be monitored rather than guessed at.
